keyTakeAways: Sean Grayson, a 31-year-old white Illinois sheriff’s deputy, is on trial for the first-degree murder of Sonya Massey, a 36-year-old Black woman who was shot in her home after a call about a suspected prowler.
The shooting occurred after Grayson, responding to a call, noticed a pan of hot water and believed it was a threat, despite Massey laughing and saying, 'I rebuke you in the name of Jesus.'
Body camera footage shows Grayson pulling out his 9 mm pistol and firing three times, hitting Massey once below the left eye.
Massey, a single mother with mental health issues, had recently been admitted to a mental health facility and made multiple 911 calls prior to the incident, which Grayson was unaware of.
Grayson's background includes multiple DUI arrests, a drunken-driving incident with a weapon, and poor performance evaluations from past policing roles.
Following the shooting, Grayson was arrested, fired from the sheriff’s department, and the trial was moved to Peoria due to national attention.
The case prompted Illinois to pass a law requiring full transparency in the background records of law enforcement candidates, including personal and employment history.
Sangamon County Sheriff Jack Campbell was forced to retire six weeks after the incident, despite his assertion that Grayson’s past did not disqualify him.

Jury selection began in Peoria, with questions focused on jurors’ relationships with law enforcement and their views on police use of force—no juror said they believed officers could use any level of force they deemed necessary.
The case has intensified national conversations about racial bias, mental health in policing, and accountability in law enforcement use of force.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Sean Grayson, a 31-year-old Illinois sheriff’s deputy, is on trial for the first-degree murder of Sonya Massey, a Black woman who was shot in her Springfield home on July 6, 2024, after a 911 call about a suspected prowler. The shooting occurred after Grayson, who had ordered the removal of a pan of hot water from her stove, interpreted her comment 'I rebuke you in the name of Jesus' as a threat and fired three times. Massey, a single mother with known mental health issues, had made multiple 911 calls prior to the incident, which Grayson was unaware of. Grayson’s background, including DUI arrests and poor performance evaluations, raised serious questions about hiring practices. Following the incident, Grayson was fired, the sheriff who hired him retired, and Illinois passed a new law requiring full transparency in law enforcement candidate background checks. The trial was moved to Peoria due to national attention and security concerns, and jury selection began with questions focused on attitudes toward police use of force—no juror believed officers could use any level of force they deemed necessary. The case has ignited broader national conversations about racial disparities, mental health in policing, and police accountability.
